verse:
भवाप्ययौ हि भूतानां श्रुतौ विस्तरशो मया |
त्वत्त: कमलपत्राक्ष माहात्म्यमपि चाव्ययम् || 2||
transliteration: bhavāpyayau hi bhūtānāṁ śhrutau vistaraśho mayātvattaḥ kamala-patrākṣha māhātmyam api chāvyayam
word meanings: bhava—appearance; apyayau—disappearance; hi—indeed; bhūtānām—of all living beings; śhrutau—have heard; vistaraśhaḥ—in detail; mayā—by me; tvattaḥ—from you; kamala-patra-akṣha—lotus-eyed one; māhātmyam—greatness; api—also; cha—and; avyayam—eternal
translation: The origin and the destruction of beings verily have been heard by me in detail from Thee, O lotus-eyed Lord, and also Thy inexhaustible greatness.
commentary: Arjun continues his appreciation of Lord Krishna’s glories by confirming his paramount position as the source of the appearance and disappearance of the entire material manifestation. He addresses Shree Krishna in the vocative with the words kamala-patrākṣha, meaning “whose eyes are like the lotus flower, which is large, soft, and beautiful, and endowed with the attributes of sweetness and gentleness.”By the above verse, Arjun implies, “O Shree Krishna, I have heard from you about your imperishable majestic glories. Although you are present within all, you are untainted by their imperfections. Although you are the supreme controller, yet you are the non-doer and are not responsible for our actions. Although you bestow the results of our karmas, you are impartial and equal to all. You are the supreme witness and the dispenser of the results of our actions. I thus conclude that you are the object of adoration of all beings.”

newest_commentary: Arjun acknowledges Lord Krishna as the source of the material world and praises his divine qualities. He describes Krishna's eyes as beautiful and compares them to the lotus flower. Arjun understands that Krishna possesses imperishable glories and remains untainted by the imperfections of the world. Although Krishna is the supreme controller, he is not responsible for the actions of individuals. Despite bestowing the fruits of their actions, he remains impartial and treats everyone equally. Krishna is the ultimate witness and the one who dispenses the results of actions. Arjun concludes that Krishna is the object of adoration for all beings.
